newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan vice-president may visit Europe - report.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan vice-president may visit Europe - report.

text.p: Taiwan officials were tight-lipped on Tuesday over a newspaper report that the isolated island's Vice-President, Lien Chan, would visit Europe on the way home from an official trip to Nicaragua.
The United Evening News, quoting unnamed high-level officials, said Lien would fly to "important" and "powerful" European nations to work on Taipei's diplomatic relationships.

Communist China, Taiwan's arch rival since a civil war split them in 1949, regards the island as a rebel province ineligible for foreign ties. It has tightened a diplomatic squeeze on Taipei in its quest to bring Taiwan under mainland rule.
"So far we are proceeding with our original plan to visit overseas. We do not intend to change the plan," Foreign Minister John Chang said on state radio.
Chang declined to comment when asked whether the original plan included a visit to Europe.
Lien, who is also premier, is scheduled to leave for Nicaragua on Tuesday to attend the January 10 inauguration of Arnoldo Aleman as president.
He will stop in New York on his way home.
Only 30 countries, mostly poor states in Africa and central America, recognise Taiwan's exiled Republic of China government instead of Beijing's communist Chinese government.
South Africa, Taiwan's biggest ally, announced in November it would sever ties with Taipei by the end of 1997 in favour of Beijing.
To evade China's diplomatic embargo, Taiwan officials have engaged in "secret diplomacy" -- unannounced visits to countries which recognise Beijing instead of Taipei.
Foreign Minister Chang and Lien have between them visited Ukraine, Singapore, Malaysia, Belgium, the United Arab Emirates and Jordan in the past year.
